1999-08-03 00:00:00+00:00	eBay's Position and Competition	['Motley Fool Staff']	"ALEXANDRA
column2: VA (August 3
column3: 1999) -- Remember when the imminent online arrival of Barnes & Noble (NYSE: BKS)
column4: Borders Group (NYSE: BGP) and even Books-A-Million (Nasdaq: BAMM) was going to destroy Amazon.com (Nasdaq: AMZN)?

column1: Likewise
column2: many predict the demise of eBay (Nasdaq: EBAY) at the hands of proliferating competitors such as Amazon
column3: Yahoo! (Nasdaq: YHOO)
column4: and Priceline.com (Nasdaq: PCLN). Can eBay be displaced? eBay is not only the so-called first mover in the consumer online auction market
column5: but it has been the first to scale into millions of users as well
column6: and that is actually much more important than even being first mover -- first to scale.

column1: As our own TMF School reminds us
column2: being first mover doesn't mean that a company is going to win. With strong management
column3: first mover status does help. With weak management
column5: a stronger company can steal a first mover's idea and be the first to scale it. Game
column7: and match is usually rewarded to the first to scale a good idea
column8: not the first mover alone. In the auction world
column9: that's eBay. It was first to move and first to scale. (Amazon is doing the same in general online commerce.)

column1: eBay's primary competition is Yahoo! Auctions
column2: Amazon
column3: uBid (Nasdaq: UBID) and Onsale (Nasdaq: ONSL). Priceline is also on the move. Last week it was reported that Priceline is considering the sale of consumer retail goods in an auction format. Similar to the site's blind bid system for airline tickets
column4: whereby a user enters the desired price for a flight and then waits to see what he gets
column5: users would enter bids for consumer goods
column6: and the seller would forage among the bids to choose the winner.

column1: Priceline's auction format doesn't sound as satisfying or convenient as the eBay system -- a system where you know who's winning an auction
column2: and you have a ballpark idea of what you need to bid to get on the leader board. Priceline's service will appeal to corporate sellers that wish to unload aging or close-out inventory
column3: however
column4: and it will appeal to adventurous buyers who don't mind bidding on items in a random

column1: But it isn't eBay. It wouldn't have the intimacy of eBay. It wouldn't have the consumer-to-consumer contact -- the friendliness that makes eBay what it is. It probably wouldn't have the reassuring rating system. And it'd likely lack the community sprit. Heck
column2: though
column3: it doesn't even have a presence yet. Priceline's idea is probably months from fruition.

column1: As Priceline ponders
column2: eBay continues to swim ahead as the dominant online auction leader
column3: and -- depending on how you measure it -- the largest online consumer retailer on the planet
column5: gross merchandise revenue at eBay was $622 million
column6: nearly twice Amazon's $314 million. Of these sales
column8: eBay collected ""only"" $38.5 million in commission revenue -- not bad for a two-year-old business. eBay's commission revenue should top $200 million this year and $340 million in 2000
column10: as gross merchandise revenue should soar into billions of dollars. All the while
column11: eBay will carry zero inventory and it should be profitable to the tune of an estimated $0.43 per share in 2000.

column1: The company ended the second quarter with 5.6 million registered users
column2: up 46% from the first quarter
column3: and pounding into the table average estimates of a high 4 million. The runner-up behind eBay is Yahoo! Auctions. Its auctions are free
column4: but beyond this the benefits compared to eBay are few. Yahoo! lacks the consumer-friendly nature of eBay (though it is improving)
column6: and the wide array of products that eBay offers.

column1: eBay currently has 2.46 million items for sale on its site
column2: up from 1.7 million this spring. It had 2.2 million items before the outage in June; that number quickly dropped to 1.8 million
column3: and then it steadily climbed again to 2.2 million. Finally
column5: it made new highs at 2.5 million. (As investors
column6: we check the number on eBay's home page regularly.) The number of registered users and items for sale on Yahoo! and Amazon are difficult (make that impossible) to obtain
column7: but estimates place them in the minor leagues compared to eBay -- hundreds of thousands compared to eBay's millions.

column1: Other competitors don't fare any better. Onsale reported second-quarter results that missed expectations. The company is merging with Egghead.com (Nasdaq: EGGS) to create more visibility. Onsale grew registered users 22% to 1.382 million last quarter
column2: making it 4.6 million users lighter than eBay. And anyway
column3: Onsale isn't even a one-on-one contender with eBay on the same broad level. It has a primary focus: selling refurbished and closeout computers
column4: peripherals and consumer electronics. It also sells sporting goods and housewares
column6: but these goods aren't the butter on its bread. The butter on its bread is computer goods from manufacturers. Therefore
column7: the site truly doesn't represent consumer-to-consumer auction competition to eBay.

column1: Due to its product offerings
column2: Onsale has higher revenue than eBay (though not higher gross merchandise revenue)
column3: but it also shows losses
column4: not profits. A key difference between Onsale and eBay is inventory. Onsale provides it. eBay doesn't. eBay leverages the Internet much more effectively. This is partially why each eBay user is valued so much higher than an auction user at any other site. eBay's users bring value (in the form of inventory) to the site

column1: Next on the block is uBid. uBid is much more a competitor to Onsale than to eBay. The company also focuses on selling refurbished consumer electronic items
column2: auction style
column3: with bids beginning at $7 per item. Over 90 manufacturers provide the usual closeout products that sell on the site. uBid's registered users totaled only 533
column5: up 41%. uBid lost $4.2 million on $45.6 million in revenue in the second quarter. On July 21
column6: uBid filed to sell 2.0 million shares of its stock to the public to raise funds. The stock is at $22
column8: and just two dollars above its all-time low.

column1: On April 12
column2: eBay sold 6.5 million shares of stock at $170 per share
column3: raising a tidy war chest at an opportune moment. From May 15 to June 14
column5: a slide instigated by the June 11 site outage. The stock recovered above $160 afterwards
column6: but since then it turned to fall to current prices on word that management would increase spending on international expansion
column8: and technology. eBay will remain profitable
column10: and management is comfortable with year 2000 earnings per share estimates.

column1: eBay has the cash
column2: market lead
column3: and an early highly scaled inventory-free business model that so many others covet. Yahoo! and Amazon are its most formidable competitors
column4: but eBay has a giant leg-up on each
column5: and it commands most mind-share for online auctions. eBay is in such a good position that it almost must mess up in order to lose its lead and momentum. The ball is in its court. eBay is the leading horse taking the first turn
column6: and there is no second place horse close behind.

column1: eBay to win
column2: place
column3: or show. And eBay to win. Our two bets. Not in that order.

column1: If you have thoughts to share on eBay
column2: please visit the Rule Breaker board.

column1: Finally
column2: be sure to read the Fool's new News World for all of today's major investment news
column3: and check out Drip Port -- today we officially begin our food and beverage industry study."

column1: 1999-06-09 01:00:00+00:00	Something for everyone	[]	"Scotland is undergoing something of a building boom right now. Demand is up
column2: prices are up
column3: sales are up - it's no wonder that house builders are whistling cheerfully as they go about their work.

column1: In a remarkable revival
column2: one housebuilder in three is reporting an increase in enquiries
column3: according to the Scottish Building Employers Federation. During the first quarter of this year
column4: 12% of all new homes started in the UK were in Scotland
column5: compared with only 10% at the same time last year.

column1: Demand is being driven by a combination of factors: low inflation
column2: low interest rates
column3: and the fact that property is currently very affordable in relation to average earnings.

column1: According to the National House Building Council (NHBC)
column2: the average price of a new home started in Scotland during the first quarter of this year was #82

column1: NHBC figures show that the average price paid for a detached property in Scotland during the first quarter of this year was #111
column2: 000. Detached bungalows cost #86
column3: 000 on average
column4: flats and maisonettes came in at #73
column6: and the average semi had a price tag of #62

column1: The cheapest new-build homes in Scotland are either terraced properties or ''attached'' bungalows. The average price for each of these over the first three months of this year was #55
But these are average prices. Those looking for homes at a lower or higher price will find plenty to choose from.
A third of all new homes in Scotland are priced at under #50
column3: a very affordable buy for many people. A further 50% of new homes north of the Border are selling at between #50

column1: Another 12% cost between #100
column4: leaving only 5% of Scotland's new homes priced at over #150
column7: at just 0.5% of all new homes sold.

column1: Despite the low sales levels at the top end
column2: an increasing number of builders are looking at that market. Miller Homes is developing a site at Paisley where properties will be priced at over #200
column3: 000 for a five-bedroom home.

column1: ''There is a demand in Scotland for new homes priced at #250
column2: 000 and upwards
column3: '' says Geoff Potton

column1: ''We will be operating across most sectors and our average selling price in Scotland is likely to be around #90
column2: 000. The market is very strong right now
column3: especially for smaller three and four-bedroom homes.''

column1: Miller Homes is expecting to build 1500 homes in the UK this year
column2: with around 1000 of them in the buoyant Scottish market. With current house price inflation running at around 5% per annum
column3: Potton believes that the rises are ''sustainable'' and that they remove any worries of an overheating in the market.

column1: CALA Homes has just lodged a planning application for 26 up-market homes in Kilmarnock
column2: the company's first development in the area. The site is a former horticultural nursery
column3: which will consist of detached homes ranging in size from 1160 sq ft to 1350 sq ft.

column1: CALA's development director Hugh Martin says that if the company is given the green light by the planners
column2: it should be on site by the autumn.

column1: ''Our development at Shanter's Wynd in Alloway is nearly sold out
column2: '' he says. ''We're hoping to continue this success in Kilmarnock.

column1: The buy-to-let sector is also driving the new homes market. In some parts of the country
column2: the number of homes being purchased for letting is reaching saturation point. But there are still plenty of investors hoping to enhance their pension by venturing into the new market.

column1: New homes can make an ideal purchase for buy-to-let
column2: but it is important to choose the location carefully.

column1: City centre flats are often a better bet than a semi in a suburban cul-de-sac. Many customers for the rented market are young professionals
column2: and are likely to prefer the social amenities of the city to a quiet life in suburbia.

column1: However
column2: there are two connected issues preoccupying builders: shortage of development land and the Government's demand for 60% of new developments to take place on brownfield sites.

column1: This ''recycling'' of industrial land offers many opportunities for builders
column2: especially since proposals for construction on greenfield sites often cause outcry. Brownfield sites need not necessarily be derelict factories or contaminated chemical works. They can consist of pleasant former hospital sites
column3: such as Mearnskirk on the South Side of Glasgow.

column1: The continuing shortage of development land is likely to push up prices
column2: making now a particularly good time to buy a new home in Scotland."
